byline.contributor: Lis Horta Moriconi contributed reporting from Rio de Janeiro.

abstract: Brazilian government struggles with burgeoning and violent prison system, with inmate population that has doubled to 550,000 since 2000; prisoners' rights group Acuda has received permission to give about 15 inmates a month ayahuasca, centuries-old hallucinogenic brew; along with therapy and meditation, goal of using ayahuasca is to expand consciousness of inmates about right, wrong and redemption.
lead_paragraph: The provision of ayahuasca, a psychedelic brew used in the Amazon basin for centuries, to inmates on short furloughs reflects a quest to ease pressure on Brazil’s prison system.

headline.main: In Brazil, Some Inmates Get Therapy With Hallucinogenic Tea
